When all of the milk has been added, transfer the mixture to the saucepan and return it to the heat. Cook, stirring constantly, over medium heat until the mixture begins to boil. Reduce the heat and cook for 30 seconds more. Remove the pan from the heat and stir in the vanilla.
Transfer the pastry cream to a bowl. Cover with plastic wrap, pressing the plastic directly against the surface. Refrigerate until chilled, at least 2 hours.
On a lightly floured surface, roll out the puff pastry to a 14 × 10-inch rectangle. Place the pastry on a large ungreased baking sheet. Refrigerate for 30 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 400°F.

With a fork, prick the dough all over. Invert an ungreased baking sheet on top of the dough. Bake for 15 minutes. Remove the top baking sheet, prick the dough again, and bake 5 to 8 minutes more, or until the pastry is golden brown. Slide the pastry onto a rack and let cool completely.

Place the pastry on a cutting board. With a serrated knife, using a sawing motion, cut the pastry crosswise into 3 equal strips. Place one strip on a serving platter. Spread with half of the pastry cream. Top with a second layer and the remaining pastry cream. Place the remaining layer on top. Dust with confectioners' sugar.
Sprinkle the mille foglie generously with confectioners' sugar. With a serrated knife, cut into 1 1/2-inch slices and serve.

recipes.name: Cannoli
recipes.description: Cannoli tubes are available at kitchenware shops, generally in sets of four. You can reuse them, but it is easier if you have at least eight to work with.

sub_recipes.name: For all-purpose flour
ingredients: Candied cherries or crushed orange peel (optional)

instructions: Line a large strainer with cheesecloth. Place the strainer over a bowl. Scrape the ricotta into the strainer and cover with a piece of plastic wrap and a small plate. Weight the plate with a heavy can. Let the ricotta drain in the refrigerator for several hours, or overnight.

In a large bowl, whisk the ricotta until smooth. Stir in the confectioners' sugar, vanilla, and cinnamon, and salt. Stir in the oil and enough wine to make a soft dough. Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface and knead it until smooth and well blended, about 2 minutes. Shape the dough into a ball. Cover with plastic wrap and let rest at room temperature for at least 30 minutes.

Cut the dough into 4 pieces. Starting at the middle setting, run one of the pieces of dough through the rollers of a pasta machine. Lightly dust the dough with flour as needed to keep the pieces from sticking together. Continue rolling the dough through progressively narrower settings until you have last setting. The dough strip should be about 4 inches wide and thin enough to see your hand through. [The dough can be rolled on a board with a rolling pin, but be sure to roll it very thin.] Measure the length of your cannoli tubes and cut the strip of dough crosswise into pieces about 1 inch shorter.
Continue rolling out the remaining dough. Work do not have enough cannoli tubes for all of the pieces at once; simply cover the remaining dough with plastic wrap until you are ready to cook them.

On the cannoli tubes. Place a cannoli tube on one piece of dough at an angle, from corner to corner. Fold the dough over to cover the tube. It should not be wrapped too tight or stretched too tight. The dough or pull it apart. Wet a little egg white on the dough where it overlaps; avoid getting egg white on the cannoli tube or it. Press the edges to seal.

Pour 2 inches of oil into a deep fryer or deep heavy saucepan. Heat to 375°F on a deep-frying thermometer. Line a baking pan with paper towels. Carefully lower a few of the cannoli tubes into the hot oil. Do not crowd the pan. Fry the shells until golden, about 2 minutes, turning them so that they brown evenly.
Using tongs, remove the cannoli tubes, holding them straight up so that the oil flows back into the pan. Drain the tubes briefly on the paper towels.

While they are still hot, carefully slide the cannoli shells from the tubes. Grasp each tube with a pot holder and pull the cannoli shell off the tube with a pair of tongs, or with your hand protected by an oven mitt or towel. Cool the shells completely on the paper towels.
The shells are fragile and break easily, so handle them carefully. (Cooked shells can be stored in an airtight container, up to 3 days.) Repeat until all the shells are cooked.

To make the ricotta cream, put the ricotta in a food processor and blend it until creamy. Add the confectioners' sugar, vanilla, and cinnamon and blend until smooth. Transfer to a bowl and stir in the chocolate chips and candied fruit. Cover and refrigerate up to 2 days. (The filling will keep in the refrigerator.)

To assemble, fill a pastry bag fitted with a 1/2-inch plain tip, or a heavy-duty plastic storage bag, with the ricotta cream. If using a plastic bag, cut about 1/2 inch off one bottom corner. Insert the tip of the bag in a cannoli shell and squeeze gently until the shell is half-filled. Turn the shell and fill from the other side. The shell should be completely filled but not overstuffed. If the ricotta mixture is too stiff, decorate the ends with candied cherries or strips of orange peel.
Place the cannoli on a serving platter and sprinkle with confectioners' sugar. Serve within 1 hour.

recipes.name: Biscotti d'Anice
instructions: Preheat the oven to 350°F. Butter a 9-inch square baking pan. Line the bottom of the pan with wax paper. Butter and flour the paper. Tap out the excess.

In a large bowl, whisk the eggs until foamy. Whisk in the extracts, and sugar. With the whisk attachment or beaters, begin beating the eggs on low speed, gradually increasing the speed to high and continue to whip the eggs for 8 to 7 minutes, until they are very light and foamy and tripled in volume.

Place the flour, cornstarch, and baking powder in a sieve. Shake about one-third of the mixture over the egg mixture. Gently but thoroughly fold in the dry ingredients. Repeat two more times with the remaining flour mixture. Fold in the anise seeds.
Scrape the batter into the prepared pan, leveling the top with a rubber spatula. Bake for 20 to 25 minutes, until the top is evenly browned and firm when touched lightly in the center.
Remove the cake from the oven and run a small knife around the sides. Invert the cake onto a cutting board and peel off the paper.
With a long serrated knife, cut the cake into 3 strips. Cut each strip into 1/4-inch-thick slices. Place the slices on a large baking sheet.
Bake the slices for 5 to 10 minutes, or until toasted and golden. Remove them from the oven and let cool on a wire rack. Store in a tightly covered container in a cool, dry place.

recipes.name: Cassata
ingredients: 2 ounces bittersweet or semisweet chocolate, chopped
1/2 cup chopped candied fruit, such as citron or orange peel

sub_recipes.name: For the Icing
ingredients: Candied or dried fruit, such as cherries, pineapple, or oranges

instructions: To make the filling, line a large strainer with cheesecloth and place it over a bowl. Scrape the ricotta into the sieve and cover with plastic wrap. Place a plate on top of the ricotta and a heavy object such as a can on the plate. Refrigerate overnight to drain the ricotta.

Beat the ricotta, confectioners' sugar, and vanilla in the bowl of an electric mixer until smooth and creamy. Fold in the chocolate and chopped candied fruit. (The filling can be made up to 24 hours ahead. Cover and refrigerate.)

To make the sponge cake, preheat the oven to 375°F. Butter two 9-inch layer cake pans. Line the bottoms with parchment paper or waxed paper or parchment paper. Butter the paper. Dust the pans with flour and tap out the excess.

recipes.name: Sfogliatelle
ingredients: 1/4 cup solid vegetable shortening or lard
ricotta, egg, vanilla, salt, and cinnamon

sub_recipes.name: For the Filling
ingredients: 1/2 cup regular semolina or Cream of Wheat cereal
1/4 cup chopped candied citron or candied orange peel

sub_recipes.name: To Assemble
ingredients: 1/2 cup solid vegetable shortening or lard

sub_recipes.name: Makes 12
ingredients: 1/4 cup solid vegetable shortening or lard

sub_recipes.name: For the Filling
ingredients: 1/2 cup fine semolina or Cream of Wheat cereal
1/4 cup chopped candied citron or candied orange peel

sub_recipes.name: To Assemble
ingredients: 1/2 cup solid vegetable shortening or lard

instructions: To make the dough, put the flour and salt in a food processor, add the shortening and butter and pulse until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs. With the machine running, add the honey and
To make the dough, put the flour and salt in a food processor, add the shortening and butter and pulse until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs. With the machine running, add the honey and

About 1/2 cup of bleached flour (all-purpose flour works good) and then you sprinkle the dough, kneading it together with a ball. Transfer the dough to a lightly floured surface. Knead the dough for 8 minutes, until it is soft. Flatten the dough into a disk and wrap it in plastic. Refrigerate for at least 1 hour, or overnight.

To make the filling, stir together the water, sugar, and semolina in a medium saucepan. Place this pan over a heated heat and simmer, stirring constantly. Cook for 5 minutes, or until the mixture thickens. Remove from the heat.
Stir in the ricotta, egg, vanilla, salt, and cinnamon. Mix in the candied citron. Cover and refrigerate until ready to use.
To shape the sfogliatelle, work the shortening and butter in a small saucepan.

On a lightly floured work surface. Place your piece on a lightly floured surface. Keep the remaining dough covered while you work. With a rolling pin, roll the dough out into a rectangle at least 24 inches long and 6 inches wide. Set the strip of dough aside while you roll out the remaining pieces in the same way.
Brush one long edge of dough with the melted shortening and butter. Place a second strip on top and repeat with more brushing. Stack and brush the remaining pieces in the same way.

Beginning at one of the narrow ends, tightly roll up the stack of dough into a log. Wrap in plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least one hour, or until firm. Cover the remaining shortening mixture and refrigerate.
Preheat the oven to 400°F. Line two large baking sheets with foil.
Cut the ends of the rolled-up dough to even them. Cut the dough into twelve 1/2-inch slices.

Place one slice cut side down on a lightly floured surface. Center a rolling pin on the slice and roll first to the top, then to the bottom until the dough is thin. Place about a tablespoonful of the filling to one side of the center. Fold the dough over and press the edges lightly to seal. Place the sfogliatelle on the prepared baking sheet. Continue making the remaining sfogliatelle in the same way.
Bake the sfogliatelle, switching the position of the baking sheets halfway through, for 20 minutes, brushing two more times with the shortening, until the pastries are golden and crisp.
Slide the sfogliatelle onto a rack to cool slightly; sprinkle with confectioners' sugar before serving.
tips: Note: sfogliatelle are best served warm. If making them ahead, let them cool completely, then refrigerate or freeze them tightly wrapped in plastic. Reheat in a 400°F oven for 10 minutes.
